conversations.content: Not of This World: Part One
Although the Firelord Agni was known to be a violent dragon who disliked the company of men, he also swore to protect any who made offerings to him.
When the Firelord began to scorch the mountainsides with his flames, a single woman went to stop the mayhem, volunteering to bring an offering that might satisfy his hunger.
Agni snorted at the pitiful suggestion. ＂My flames shall spread and engulf this world, which exists only for my pleasure. What could you, a mere human, possibly offer unto me?＂
When the fearless woman claimed she had something not of this world, Agni bellowed laughter. ＂Not of this world? Ha ha! You speak nonsense in the face of death.＂
In response, the woman lifted a platter piled high with the finest recipes from all across the land. The smell of it was intoxicating.
Agni was taken aback, for he knew nothing of the culinary arts.
For the first time in his life, he felt a lust for food instead of a simple urge to eat, and devoured all of the woman's offerings in a single, massive bite.
Not of This World: Part Two
Agni licked his claws, searching for a last morsel of the woman's offering. ＂I thought I had eaten all this world had,＂ he said finally, ＂but never have I tasted the like of your dish.＂
The woman responded, ＂We humans have the ability to create new things from the old and familiar of the world. This is our talent.＂
＂And so long as I live, I will bring you a new dish every year—each more delicious than the last.＂
＂In one hundred years, my children will bring you a dish with flavors I could never conceive of—and even ten thousand years hence will you still enjoy the fruits of this labor.＂
＂How novel,＂ chuckled Agni, ＂to swear that your descendants will do as much. And yet, I trust that your skill will carry on, and dearly wish to savor the results of it.＂
Agni laughed, satisfied with the deal. And with that, the Firelord and woman sealed an eternal truce, and he never again caused trouble for humans.
Tasty offerings are still made to the dragon to this very day—and he loves nothing more than to see what human ingenuity can conjure up.
